Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of the SCR experimental setup. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 NO conversion over different catalysts. (a) fresh and Se(SeO2)-doped 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalysts with different Se: V molar ratios at 200 °C and 250 °C; (b) fresh and Se(SeO2)-doped 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalysts at 300 °C and 400 °C. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 NO conversion over fresh and Se(SeO2)-doped 1 V/TiO2, 10 W/TiO2 and TiO2 samples at (a) 250 °C and (b) 300 °C. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 NO conversion over fresh and Se(SeO2)-doped 1 V-10 W/TiO2 samples with different [NH3]: [NO] ratios at 250 °C. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectra of Se 3d: (a) Se exp-250 °C; (b) SeO2 exp-250 °C (The pink area represents for metallic Se and the blue area represents for SeO2). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XPS spectra of Se 3d: (a) xSe-1 V-10 W/TiO2; (b) xSeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2 (c) 5Se-1 V/TiO2; (d) 5Se-10 W/TiO2 (The pink area represents for metallic Se, the red area represents for VxSeyOz and the blue area represents for SeO2). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XPS spectra of V 2p: (a) xSe-1 V-10 W/TiO2; (b) xSeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2 (The blue area represents for VO2, the red area represents for V2O5 and the yellow area represents for VxSeyOz). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 7 Fig. 8 H2-TPR experimental results. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Low-temperature NH3-TPD results: (a) xSe-1 V-10 W/TiO2; (b) xSeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2; (c) xSe-1 V/TiO2; (d) xSe-10 W/TiO2. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 High-temperature NH3-TPD results. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Py-FT-IR results at 100 °C: (a) xSe-1 V-10 W/TiO2; (b) xSeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Schematic diagram of Se and SeO2 poisoning mechanism. Fig. 12 Table 1 Mass of each catalyst used in each NH3-SCR performance test. Table 4 B acid amount (μmol/g) L acid amount (μmol/g) Total acid amount (μmol/g) 1 V-10 W/TiO2 91.45 113.02 204.47 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 66.10 112.44 178.54 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 exp-400 °C 22.48 64.22 86.70 5SeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2 109.39 201.65 311.04 5SeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2 exp-400 °C 36.08 55.84 91.92 Effects of Se and SeO2 on the denitrification performance of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 SCR catalyst Zhong Liu a Jian Han b Li Zhao b Yang-wen Wu b Han-xiao Wang b Xin-qi Pei b Ming-xin Xu b Qiang Lu b ⁎ Yong-ping Yang b a School of Energy, Power and Mechanical Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, 102206, China School of Energy Power and Mechanical Engineering North China Electric Power University Beijing 102206 China School of Energy, Power and Mechanical Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, China, 102206 b National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Power Generation Equipment, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, 102206, China National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Power Generation Equipment North China Electric Power University Beijing 102206 China National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Power Generation Equipment, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, China, 102206 ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Various trace elements in flue gas emitted from coal combustion can cause the deactivation of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) catalysts, yet rare studies have been reported on selenium species. Herein, the effects of Se and SeO2 on the denitrification performance of commercial V2O5-WO3/TiO2 SCR catalyst were investigated. Results indicated that the activities of Se and SeO2-doped catalysts were significantly inhibited at temperatures above 250 °C. During the NH3-SCR process, metallic Se was oxidized by V2O5 to generate Se4+ (SeO2 and binary oxides VxSeyOz), while part of Se4+ was reduced to Se by NH3. Se and SeO2 deactivated the catalyst by consuming V2O5 and NH3 during the NH3-SCR process, covering the active sites and relieved the redox performance of catalysts. With the sublimation of Se and SeO2, the deactivation effect on the catalyst was greatly relieved, while the presence of residual VxSeyOz resulted in the incomplete recovery of the catalyst activity. Keywords SCR catalyst V2O5-WO3/TiO2 Se SeO2 Deactivation 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxide (NOx) is an important pollutant emitted from coal combustion process which poses a significant threat to the environment. NOx can cause acid rain, ozone depletion and photochemical smog, damaging the ecological environment and endangering human health [1,2]. Among various NOx control technologies, the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) method is the most widely used one with the advantages of high selectivity, high stability and high denitrification efficiency. During the SCR process, NOx reacts with ammonia (NH3) and oxygen to obtain nitrogen and water [3–5]. Currently, V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst is the commonest commercial SCR catalyst for the denitrification of flue gas from coal-fired power plants, diesel exhaust gas from mobile applications, and so on. During the actual working process, many components in the complex flue gas may lead to the deactivation of SCR catalyst, including alkali and alkaline earth metals (K, Na, Ca, Mg) as well as other species (As, Pb, Zn, S, P) [6–16]. Alkali and alkaline earth metals can react with the Brønsted acidic sites (VOH) on the SCR catalyst to form V-O-M (M represent alkali and alkaline earth metals), hindering the adsorption of NH3 and inhibiting the reaction between NH3 and NOx. In addition, alkaline earth metal species such as Ca can also cause severe physical deactivation of the catalyst. For instance, CaO can react with SO3, forming CaSO4 on the catalyst surface to block the pores and reduce the specific surface area [6–9]. Heavy metals such as As, Pb and Zn are also poisonous to the SCR catalyst [10–13]. They are highly toxic and chemically stable, which deposit on the SCR catalyst, resulting in masking and chemical deactivation of the active sites on catalysts. Therefore, it is essential to understand the deactivation mechanism of the SCR catalyst caused by different factors, which is helpful to the regeneration of the deactivated catalysts and the development of novel anti-contamination catalysts. As one of the main trace elements in flue gas, selenium (mainly in the forms of Se and SeO2) was released for about 459.4 tons in 2010 by coal-fired power plants in China [17]. Selenium exists as the inorganic or organic bound state in coal and mainly volatilizes as SeO2 during coal combustion. Part of SeO2 in flow gas will be reduced to metallic Se by SO2 or captured by CaO in fly ash [18]. Till now, the effects of selenium species (Se and SeO2) on the denitrification performance of SCR catalyst have rarely been reported. Therefore, it is necessary and meaningful to understand the detailed effects of selenium species on SCR catalyst. In this study, V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst was prepared and then loaded with different amounts of selenium species. These catalysts were subjected to the NH3-SCR performance tests under different temperatures as well as a series of characterizations including physical properties, X-ray fluorescence (XRF), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR), temperature programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine (Py-FT-IR). Based on the characterization results, the poisoning mechanism of Se and SeO2 on SCR catalyst was proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The fresh V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst with 1 wt.% V2O5, 10 wt.% WO3 and 89 wt.% TiO2 was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. Typically, 6.43 g ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3) and 58.11 g ammonium metatungstate ([NH4]6W7O24·6H2O) were dissolved in 335 mL deionized water with 1 mL ethanolamine as the cosolvent, and then mixed with 445 g anatase TiO2 (purchased from Chongqing Xinhua company of China with the surface area of 115.3 m2/g and particle size of 10–30 nm). After stirring for 2 h, the mixture was dried at 105 °C for 3 h and then calcined at 550 °C for 3 h. Finally, the fresh catalyst was sieved to obtain particles within the size of 300–450 μm for following treatment and tests. The obtained fresh catalyst was abbreviated as 1 V-10 W/TiO2. Based on the fresh 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst, Se-doped and SeO2-doped catalysts were prepared. The Se-doped catalysts were obtained by mechanically mixing of the fresh 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst and Se particles (74 μm) based on Se: V molar ratios of 1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1, and 5:1, respectively. The Se contents of obtained Se-doped catalysts were 0.83 wt.%, 1.66 wt.%, 2.49 wt.%, 3.33 wt.%, and 4.16 wt.%, respectively, which were recorded as xSe-1 V-10 W/TiO2 (x represented the molar ratio of Se to V). The SeO2-doped catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. SeO2 was dissolved in deionized water and mixed with 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst at Se: V molar ratios of 1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1, and 5:1, respectively. After thoroughly mixing and drying, the catalysts were finally sieved into 300–450 μm particles for experiments and characterizations. The SeO2 contents of obtained SeO2-doped catalysts were 1.15 wt.%, 2.30 wt.%, 3.45 wt.%, 4.60 wt.%, 5.75 wt.%, respectively, recorded as xSeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2 (x represented the molar ratio of Se to V). In addition, pure TiO2, 1 V/TiO2, and 10 W/TiO2 samples were also prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method to investigate the effects of Se and SeO2 on different components of the fresh 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst. They were doped with 4.16 wt.% Se or 5.75 wt.% SeO2 and recorded as 5Se(SeO2)-1 V/TiO2, 5Se(SeO2)-10 W/TiO2 and 5Se(SeO2)-TiO2. The catalysts after activity tests were labeled by a suffix of exp-y (y indicating the test temperature). For example, the 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst after testing at 400 °C was recorded as 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 exp-400. 2.2 Activity measurement The NH3-SCR tests of the catalysts were conducted in a fixed-bed reactor, as shown in Fig. 1 . During the test, each gas flow was accurately controlled by a mass flow meter, then mixed in a gas mixing tank before entering the SCR denitrification reactor. When NH3-SCR tests started, the data achieved stabilization within different times at 200–400 °C. Stable data were then continuously collected. The concentrations of nitrogen oxides at the inlet and outlet of the reactor were detected by the MGA5 full infrared smoke analyzer (Germany MRU company). The total gas flow rate was 3000 mL/min, consisting of 458 ppm NO, 503 ppm NH3, 2.4 vol% O2, and N2 as the balance gas. The SCR activity was tested at 200–250 °C for 20 min and 300–400 °C for 3 h, respectively. In order to ensure the amount of active component V2O5 was consistent when using different catalysts, the dosage of each catalyst was varied, as shown in Table 1 . The denitrification performance was evaluated with the NO conversion (X). (1) X = C N O , i n _ C N O , o u t C N O , i n × 100% Where X was the denitrification efficiency, C N O , i n a n d C N O , o u t were the concentrations of NO in the flue gas before and after the catalytic reaction, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The physical properties of the catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption at −196.15 °C using an automated gas sorption analyzer (Quantachrome, Autosorb-Iq-MP, US). The samples were degassed under vacuum at 100 °C for 4 h before measurement. The pretreatment was conducted at such a low temperature to avoid the SeO2 removal from the catalyst. The surface area was calculated by Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method. The total pore volume and average pore diameter were derived from the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The XRF analysis was carried out by an X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (Shimadzu, XRF-1800, Japan) to determine the proportions of chemical components in the samples. The X-ray tube target was Rh with the pressure of 60 kV (Max), the detection concentration was 10−6–100%. The minimum analysis diameter was 250 μm, and the maximum scanning rate was 300°/min. The XPS analysis results were obtained on an XPS electron spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, Escalab 250Xi, US) using 150 W Al Kα (hv =1486.6 eV) as the radiation source. The C1s lined at 284.8 eV from the carbon was used as a reference for binding energies calibration. The NH3-TPD and H2-TPR analyses were performed with a chemisorption analyzer (Quantachrome, Chembet_Pulsar, US). The NH3-TPD analyses were conducted in two ways, i.e., low-temperature NH3-TPD and high-temperature NH3-TPD. For the low-temperature NH3-TPD, the catalyst samples adsorbed NH3 for 1 h at 100 °C and heated from 100 °C to 250 °C with the heating rate of 10 °C/min and kept for 1 h to avoid the influence of SeO2 sublimation on the experimental results. For the high-temperature NH3-TPD, the tested catalysts at 400 °C with little SeO2 content adsorbed NH3 at 100 °C for 1 h and heated from 100 °C to 800 °C with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The H2-TPR results were obtained from heating of the catalyst samples from room temperature to 800 °C with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The Py-FT-IR analysis was carried out on an infrared spectrometer (Thermo Nicolet Corporation, Nicolet IS10, US) with a 0.4 cm−1 resolution, a 400–4000 cm−1 scanning range, and accumulating 32 scans per spectrum. Prior to the experiment, the samples were pretreated by evacuation at 120 °C for 1 h, and then absorbed pyridine at room temperature for 1 h, the spectra were recorded at 100 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR performance of the catalysts The catalytic activities of fresh and Se(SeO2)-doped catalysts at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 2 . According to Fig. 2a, the loading of Se and SeO2 had slight effects on the NO conversion at 200 °C, but significantly inhibited the catalytic activities at 250 °C. Moreover, the inhibiting effect of Se was stronger than that of SeO2. When the reaction temperature rose above 300 °C, Se and SeO2 continued to observably reduce the catalyst activities as shown in Fig. 2b. It was also noteworthy that as the experiment proceeded, the activities of the catalysts would slowly increase to some extent, due to the removal of Se and SeO2 during the test process. In order to further determine the interaction effects between Se, SeO2 and SCR catalyst components, the activities of 1 V/TiO2, 10 W/TiO2 and TiO2 samples doped with 4.16 wt.% Se and 5.75 wt.% SeO2 were tested. As shown in Fig. 3 , the presence of Se and SeO2 significantly decreased the NO conversion of 1 V/TiO2 sample, but had little effect on 10 W/TiO2 and TiO2 samples at 250 °C and 300 °C. The results clearly indicated that Se mainly interacted with V2O5 component to poison the SCR catalyst. Fig. 4 shows the denitrification activity of 5Se(SeO2)-1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst with different [NH3]: [NO] ratios at 250 °C. With [NH3]: [NO] ratio increased from 1.1 to 1.5, the NO conversion of 1 V-10 W/TiO2 maintained at 67.12%. While for 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 and 5SeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2, the NO conversion increased from 9.64% to 14.35% and 14.41% to 20.45%, respectively. This indicated that the selenium species would compete NH3 with V2O5, which might have a negative effect on NH3-SCR reaction. 3.2 Physical properties and chemical components of the catalysts Tables 2 and 3 show the physical properties and chemical components of fresh and Se(SeO2)-doped catalysts. After doping Se and SeO2, the specific surface area (Sa) and pore volume (Vp) of the catalyst decreased and the mean pore diameter (Dp) increased, which should be resulted from the blocking of micropores in the catalysts. It is known that both SeO2 and Se have poor thermal stability [19], with the sublimation and melting temperatures around 315 °C and 217 °C under atmospheric pressure. As a result, they would gradually sublimate and evaporate during the test process. According to Table 3, the SeO2 contents of Se(SeO2)-doped catalysts decreased slightly from 5.08 wt.% and 5.98 wt.% to 4.76 wt.% and 5.31 wt.% after the tests at 250 °C, but significantly decreased to as low as 0.78 wt.% and 0.31 wt.% after the tests at 400 °C. The sublimation of SeO2 also recovered the textual properties of the catalysts. However, the catalytic efficiency was not fully recovered, reaching only 60.85% and 74.83% of the fresh catalyst for 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 and 5SeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2 tested at 400 °C, respectively. The results suggested that the decrease in catalyst activity of Se(SeO2)-doped catalysts was caused not only by physical factors but also chemical factors. 3.3 Chemical states of the catalysts Se or SeO2 would undergo oxidation or reduction reactions during the SCR process. In order to explore the chemical states of selenium species in the experimental environment without any catalyst, 3 mL Se or SeO2 powders were placed in the SCR reactor at 250 °C for 10 min and then removed for XPS analysis. The XPS spectra of the Se 3d are shown in Fig. 5 . The binding energies peaked at 54–57 eV and 58–61 eV were attributed to Se0 and Se4+, respectively [20]. Fig. 5a showed that Se0 maintained zero-valent after the experiment, indicating that Se0 could not be oxidized under the tested condition. In Fig. 5b, about 10% of SeO2 was reduced to Se0 after being tested in flue gas at 250 °C for 10 min. The reason that SeO2 was not completely reduced might be the short reaction time and the remaining SeO2 was covered by the generated Se and separated from the ammonia gas. Generally, in the absence of catalysts, SeO2 would be reduced to Se by NH3, while Se would not be oxidized back to SeO2 in the flow gas. The reduction reaction could be proposed as follows. (2) 3SeO2 + 4NH3 = 3Se + 6H2O + 2N2 Besides the pure Se and SeO2, the fresh and used Se(SeO2)-doped catalysts were also subjected for XPS analyses to reveal the changes of selenium species in the presence of the catalyst. The XPS spectra of Se 3d are shown in Fig. 6 . According to 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst in Fig. 6a, the peak area of Se0 was greatly decreased after the catalytic performance test at 250 °C. Meanwhile, two new peaks of Se4+ appeared at 59.0 eV and 59.7 eV, corresponding to VxSeyOz and SeO2. The results clearly indicated that most of the Se0 was oxidized to Se4+ with two combinations by 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst, which were totally different from the results in the absence of the catalyst. Kohli et al. prepared (V2O5)100-xSex (x = 9, 17, 25, 30 wt.%) by Se0 and V2O5, of which the Se 3d XPS spectra showed that Se0 would be oxidized to Se4+ by V5+ in the heating process [21]. Therefore, it is reasonable to infer that there would be a solid-solid reaction between the V2O5 in 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst and metallic Se. Moreover, previous studies confirmed that solid-state SeO2 could combine with V4+ to generate VOSe2O5 or VO(SeO2OH)2 by forming V-O-Se-O-V group [22–24]. According to above analysis, it could be inferred that Se0 would be oxidized to Se4+ during the SCR reaction and part of Se4+ combined with VOx to form binary oxides VxSeyOz, which would also be confirmed by the XPS results of V species in the catalysts. Whereas, after the catalytic performance test at 400 °C, SeO2 could no longer be detected due to its sublimation, only leaving a little VxSeyOz in the catalyst, agreed well with the XRF analysis results in Table 3. In regard to the 5SeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalysts in Fig. 6b, the peak area of SeO2 was slightly reduced after the catalytic performance test at 250 °C. Meanwhile, two new peaks of Se0 and VxSeyOz appeared at 55.5 eV and 59.0 eV, indicating SeO2 would be reduced to Se0 and combine with VOx to form VxSeyOz. Comparing Fig. 6a and b, it could be seen that 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst produced more VxSeyOz than 5SeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst after the catalytic performance test at 250 °C. This indicated that Se was easier to react with VOx and to generate VxSeyOz comparing with SeO2. The formation of stable VxSeyOz suggested that V5+ with high catalytic activity was reduced to low-valent V4+, resulting in the poisoning of the SCR catalyst. Since the formation of VxSeyOz from Se-doped catalyst was more than that of SeO2-doped catalyst, it was concluded that Se was more poisonous to the SCR catalyst than SeO2, which agreed with the results of SCR performance tests illustrated in Fig. 2. In order to further determine which component in 1 V-10 W/TiO2 oxidized Se to SeO2, the Se 3d spectra of 5Se-1 V/TiO2 and 5Se-10 W/TiO2 before and after usage are shown in Fig. 6c and 6 d. Comparing Fig. 6c with d, it could be found that Se was easily oxidized by 1 V/TiO2 catalyst, but could not be oxidized by 10 W/TiO2 catalyst, which further indicating that only V2O5 was responsible for the oxidation of Se to SeO2. Based on the above results, when Se or SeO2 was doped on 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst, an additional cycle of Se → SeO2 → Se occurred during the denitrification process. Since the reduction of SeO2 required the participation of NH3, the amount of NH3 reacted with NO would be decreased. In addition, the oxidation of Se0 on the catalyst would reduce the valence state of V5+ and form VxSeyOz to occupy the catalytic active sites and affect the redox property. These factors would be detrimental to the denitrification reaction. In order to further explore the interaction between Se species and V species during the catalytic reaction, the XPS results of V 2p are shown in Fig. 7 . The binding energies around 515.8 eV and 517.0 eV could be attributed to VO2 and V2O5, respectively [25,26]. For the Se(SeO2)-doped catalysts, a new peak appeared at 518.2 eV after the catalytic performance test at 250 °C. According to above analysis results, this peak was attributed to VxSeyOz. The formation of VxSeyOz might prevent the redox cycle of V species and covered the acidic sites on the surface of catalyst, thereby deactivating the catalyst. 3.4 Redox properties of the catalysts The redox properties of the catalysts were elucidated by H2-TPR analyses. Fig. 8 shows the H2-TPR results of fresh and Se(SeO2)-doped catalysts after the catalytic performance tests at 400 °C. Two peaks could be observed on the fresh sample, the low-temperature peak at 400∼500 °C could be assigned to the reduction of V5+ to V3+, while the high-temperature peak near 690 °C was ascribed to the reduction of W6+ to W0 [27]. As seen from Fig. 8, the loading of Se or SeO2 had little effect on the redox performance of W6+, but changed the reduction peak of V5+ remarkably. The reduction peak in the range of 400–500 °C changed from a single peak to a shoulder peak, and the peak area increased significantly, indicating that a new reduction reaction occurred during the experiment and interacted with the reduction of vanadium. According to previous inference, the new reaction should be the reduction of Se4+ to Se0. Furthermore, the increase in the peak area of Se poisoned catalyst in low-temperature range was smaller than that of SeO2 poisoned catalyst, which could be explained by the V5+ consumption when Se0 was oxidized to Se4+. 3.5 Surface acidity of the catalysts The NH3-TPD analyses were performed to characterize the surface acidity of the catalysts, which was important to SCR reaction [28,29]. In order to avoid the sublimation of SeO2 affecting the experimental results, low-temperature NH3-TPD was conducted at 250 °C for 1 h, with the results shown in Fig. 9 . This program could not indicate the change in the acid strength of the catalyst, but could reflect the change in the amount of the weak acid sites. As seen from Fig. 9a and b, the desorption peak area of the catalyst decreased slightly after Se doping, but increased significantly after SeO2 doping. This indicated that a small amount of Se covered on the acidic sites of the catalyst, while SeO2 could provide additional acid sites. After the catalytic performance test at 250 °C, the desorption peak area of 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 increased significantly, while the peak area of 5SeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2 did not show significant changes, which indicated that part of Se was oxidized to SeO2, subsequently increasing the surface acidity of the catalyst. The additional acid sites brought by SeO2 would be beneficial to the SCR reaction, which seemed to cover the negative effects of selenium species, leading to a slight increase in NO conversion at 200 °C as shown in Fig. 2a. The desorption peak areas of 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 and 5SeO2-1 V-10 W/TiO2 were less than 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst after the catalytic performance test at 400 °C, which should be attributed to the fact that the original acid site provider V2O5 was partially converted into VxSeyOz. The low-temperature NH3-TPD results of 1 V/TiO2 and 10 W/TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 9c and d. The acidity of 5Se-1 V/TiO2 after the catalytic performance test at 250 °C was stronger than before, while the acidity of 5Se-10 W/TiO2 did not change significantly. This phenomenon proved that V2O5 could promote the oxidation of Se0 to SeO2, while WO3 and TiO2 could hardly affect the valence of Se species, which was consistent with the results obtained by Kohli et al. [21]. In order to fully determine the changes in the total acid amounts of the catalysts, high-temperature NH3-TPD results of fresh and Se(SeO2)-doped catalysts tested at 400 °C are shown in Fig. 10 . The desorption peak areas of Se(SeO2)-doped catalysts tested at 400 °C were significantly reduced compared with the fresh catalyst. The peak area of Se-doped catalyst decreased more than that of SeO2-doped catalyst. However, the desorption curve of Se-doped catalyst was higher than that of fresh catalyst at the NH3-TPD experimental temperature (550–630 °C). According to the XPS characterization results, 5Se-1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst still had some VxSeyOz residue after the 400 °C experiment. Therefore, it was speculated that the rise in the desorption curve of Se poisoned catalyst was caused by the decomposition of VxSeyOz. The Py-FT-IR technique was used to investigate the different effects of selenium species on Brønsted acid (B) sites and Lewis acid (L) sites of 1 V-10 W/TiO2 catalyst. The results are shown in Fig. 11 . The spectra mainly showed four adsorption bands. Bands at 1447 cm−1 and 1610 cm−1 were ascribed to Lewis acid sites, bands at 1540 cm−1 were attributed to Brønsted acid sites, and bands at 1490 cm−1 were ascribed to the combination of Brønsted acid and Lewis acid sites [30,31]. The amounts of acid sites on the catalysts are shown in Table 4 , which were evaluated by the peak areas of 1447 cm−1 for Lewis acid sites and 1540 cm−1 for Brønsted acid sites. According to Fig. 11 and Table 4, it could be concluded that the loading of Se slightly reduced the amount of total acid sites and the effect on Brønsted acid sites (VOH) was much greater than that of Lewis acid sites (VO), indicating that Se could more easily be adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites (VOH). However, the loading of SeO2 increased the amount of Brønsted acid sites (SeOH) and Lewis acid sites (SeO). This result was consistent with the NH3-TPD results that SeO2 could increase the acid amount of the catalyst. After the experiment at 400 °C, the acid site amounts of the poisoned catalysts were greatly reduced and lower than that of the fresh catalyst. During the high-temperature experiment process, the acid sites brought by SeO2 were lost due to sublimation, while the other acid decreases were derived from the VOx acidity lost after the formation of VxSeyOz. 3.6 Proposed deactivation mechanism of selenium species poisoning Based on above characterization results, the behavior of Se and SeO2 on the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst could be described in Fig. 12 . When selenium species were in contact with the catalyst surface during the denitrification process, Se would be oxidized by V2O5 to form SeO2 and VxSeyOz, while SeO2 could be reduced to Se by NH3, forming the species cycle of Se → SeO2 → Se in the system. V2O5 was consumed in this cycle, which inhibited the SCR reaction and the redox performance of vanadium species. When the reaction temperature rose, Se and SeO2 would gradually remove from the catalyst surface. High temperature could restore part of the catalytic activity, but the stable VxSeyOz would continue to remain on the catalyst, covering the active sites and inhibiting the full recover of the catalyst activity. Combined with the characterization results, the formation of VxSeyOz could be explained as following. Firstly, Se was oxidized and combined with Brønsted acid sites (VOH) to form group 1, which provided more acid sites such as SeOH and SeO. Secondly, group 1 broke down to SeO2 which sublimated from the catalyst as the temperature increased, resulting in the decrease of acid amount. Finally, Se reacted and combined with Lewis acid sites (VO) to form group 2 (VxSeyOz), further decreasing the acid sites. 4 Conclusions In this work, the effect of different Se and SeO2 contents on denitrification performance of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst were studied at different temperatures. NH3-SCR tests showed that the doping of Se and SeO2 had slight effect on the denitrification efficiencies at 200 °C, but exhibited a significant negative effect above 250 °C. A series of characterizations were performed to analyze the deactivation mechanism of Se(SeO2)-doped catalysts. The characterization results indicated that the decrease in catalyst activity was caused both by physical and chemical factors. The doping of Se and SeO2 would block the micropores in the catalysts. SeO2 could be reduced by NH3 to generate Se, while Se would be oxidized by V2O5 to form a redox reaction during the experiment, which would consume the high-valence vanadium species and NH3 to deactivate the catalyst. In addition, selenium species would combine with vanadium species to form the compound VxSeyOz, which caused the impairment of redox performance and the reducing of acid sites concentration, further suppressed the SCR activity. With the increase of the reaction temperature, the removal of Se and SeO2 greatly relieved the deactivation of selenium species on the catalyst, while the residual VxSeyOz resulted in the incomplete recovery of the catalyst activity. coredata.dc:description: Various trace elements in flue gas emitted from coal combustion can cause the deactivation of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) catalysts, yet rare studies have been reported on selenium species. Herein, the effects of Se and SeO2 on the denitrification performance of commercial V2O5-WO3/TiO2 SCR catalyst were investigated. Results indicated that the activities of Se and SeO2-doped catalysts were significantly inhibited at temperatures above 250 °C. During the NH3-SCR process, metallic Se was oxidized by V2O5 to generate Se4+ (SeO2 and binary oxides VxSeyOz), while part of Se4+ was reduced to Se by NH3. Se and SeO2 deactivated the catalyst by consuming V2O5 and NH3 during the NH3-SCR process, covering the active sites and relieved the redox performance of catalysts. With the sublimation of Se and SeO2, the deactivation effect on the catalyst was greatly relieved, while the presence of residual VxSeyOz resulted in the incomplete recovery of the catalyst activity.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of Se and SeO2 on the denitrification performance of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 SCR catalyst
